items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued, because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon, overnight tonight and into tomorrow morning. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Be ready to take action to protect your property, if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 4th December 2021.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning on 04/12/2021 between 08:00 AM and 10:00 AM.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Still water levels associated with the spring tides may cause water to cover areas of the Quomps and other locations close to the harbour side..
We will close flood gates in the area on Saturday morning, but they will re-open at around mid-day.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.
We will remove this message by 12:00 noon on 04/12/2021.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent remains in force. River levels have risen as a result of rainfall and snowmelt over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday, 04/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon 04/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 14:15 on 04/12/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 20 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 04/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on Saturday 04/12/2021, from 16:30-18:45. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, 04/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The forecast high water is 06:15 on Saturday morning, 04/12/21, with a level of 6.48 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal areas and the most vulnerable properties is possible and may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. High spring tides will continue until Tuesday 07/12/21 and this flood alert may remain in force although the wind strength is forecast to reduce.

Please consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 04/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 10:45 AM on Saturday 04/12/2021.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 09:45 and 12:45 AM on Saturday 04/12/2021.

No flooding of properties is expected.

The next high astronomical tide is not expected to reach flood alert level. We will remove this message once this current tide has passed.

Take care planning driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 10.45am on 04/12/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.
The forecast is for strong winds throughout the day. This may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this morning.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for this evening's or tomorrow's high tides.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the forecast high water is 06:45am on 04/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.38 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 7 in a North West direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton, however conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.

Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. 

Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 

Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast on 04/12/2021.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge from 11:15 AM on 04/12/2021. 

River levels at Fiddlers Ferry will peak at 6.9m between 11:15 AM and 12:30 PM
River levels at Eastford Road will peak at 6.73m between 11:30 AM and 12:30 PM
River levels at Arpley Bridge will peak at 6.79m between 11:45 AM and 12:45 PM

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next two days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A series of high spring tides and strong winds are likely to cause high tidal peaks in the Wye Estuary over the next 4 days until Tuesday 07/12/21. Current levels for the next tide this evening are below the flood alert threshold, however Newport may exceed the flood alert threshold on Saturday morning 04/12/21. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.5m at 06:45 on 04/12, Newport 6.9m to 7.2m at 06:45 on 04/12. Conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 04/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Saturday morning's tide at 10:45 on 04/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 5.21 metres Chart Datum (2.48 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Impacts will be minor and confined to the immediate sea front. For 15 minutes either side of high tide, water will be high at South Street and Queen Street, Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park, Langstone may flood. Water may flow into the bottom third of Langstone High Street, but flood depths in the road will be very shallow. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected, although a tide of a similar magnitude is currently forecast on Tuesday (07/12/2021). We may issue further advice on Monday (06/12/2021). We continue to monitor the forecast, and only if required, may lower levels in Emsworth Mill Pond over the weekend. As a precautionary measure, if you live directly on the harbour front, and have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 04/12/2021.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
As a result of spring tides and strong winds, the high tide water level may overtop sea defences in some locations although the flooding of properties is not forecast. The forecast high water is 06:15 on Saturday morning, 04/12/21, with a level of 6.48 mAOD and a Force 7 North Westerly wind. 
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
As a result, the flooding of coastal areas including roads and farmland, is possible at these times and may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas at risk include Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour. This flood alert is unlikely to be reissued during this period of spring tides. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates.
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 04/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Light winds and small waves with Friday evening's tide at 22:30 on 03/12/21 will generate minimal impacts. This message is issued for Saturday morning's tide at 10:45 on 04/12/21 which is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Westerly Force 6 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.14 m. The total forecast tide is 6.23 metres Chart Datum (3.18 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Strong winds will continue until Sunday, but minimal flood impacts are expected as Saturday evening's tide should be 25 cm lower than in the morning. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recycled shingle in November and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 14:00 on 04/12/21.

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Halton, Knowsley, Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast on 04/12/2021. Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Mersey Estuary.

River levels at Hale Village will peak at 6.05m between 10:45 AM and 12:45 PM.

We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next two days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 05/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea at New Brighton
items.message:
Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this morning.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at Marine Point Leisure and Retail Park.
Flooding is affecting Marine Point Leisure and Retail Park between 10:15 AM and 12:15 PM on 04/12/2021.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 04/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Arpley Bridge, Warrington
items.message:
Todays tide is expected to be higher than usual. Flooding is expected at parts of Chester Road between 11:45 AM and 12:45 PM on 04/12/2021. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled. We will continue to monitor the forecast.
We will remove this message by 06:00 PM on 04/12/2021.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: The flood alert for the lower river Derwent remains in force. River levels have risen as a result of snow-melt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday, 04/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, 04/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Camel excluding Wadebridge and Chapel Amble
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
This message has been updated for Saturday’s high tides. 

Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning and evening. High water at Padstow is at 04:44 and 17:08, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Strong force 7-8 north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. 

Locations particularly at risk include the A389 at Sladesbridge 

Expect tides to be around 200mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.  

This message will be updated on Sunday morning.  There is a possibility that further alerts may be required for Monday morning’s high tide.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning and evening. High water at St Ives is at 04:28 and 16:51, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 7 to 8, north westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 4m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations including St Ives Harbour, Portreath Harbour and the Causeway at Hayle.
Expect tides to be around 200mm higher than predicted because of forecast weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
This message will be updated on Sunday morning.  There is a possibility that further alerts may be required for Monday morning’s high tide.

items.description: Beaulieu estuary
items.message: Saturday morning's tide at 10:23 on 04/12/2021 and 12:24 on 04/12/2021 is higher than normal, due to unsettled weather with strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 4.18 metres Chart Datum (2.18 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 15 minutes either side of high water, the tide may flood into the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. Very minor flooding of Palace Lane is also possible. This could make accessing the village temporarily more difficult. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected, although a tide of a similar magnitude is currently forecast on Tuesday (07/12/2021). We may issue further advice on Monday (06/12/2021). We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide may flood the main road quickly. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 04/12/2021.

items.description: Mansbridge and Riverside Park
items.message: Saturday morning's tide at 10:23 on 04/12/2021 and 12:24 on 04/12/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 5.10 metres Chart Datum (2.36 mAOD) at Southampton. For 30 minutes either side of high water, levels in the lower River Itchen will increase, as the incoming tide prevents water from flowing out to sea. Footpath flooding may affect some areas of Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge may also experience minor impact flooding, for a very short period of time. Any flood depth will be relatively shallow. The tide will not flood property or the A27. After this tide‚ no further impacts are expected, although a tide of a similar magnitude is currently forecast on Tuesday (07/12/2021). We may issue further advice on Monday (06/12/2021). We continue to monitor the forecast. As a very precautionary measure, please consider closing the defence gates around the pub. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 04/12/2021.

All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding of coastal areas including roads and farmland is possible at these times. However, conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are coastal areas at Dunster Beaches, Blue Anchor, Steart, Stolford and Brean.  Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point and this flood alert is unlikely to be reissued during this period of spring tides. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are closing flood gates.

items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Areas most at risk include the Fiddlers Ferry area.
Flooding is affecting the Fiddlers Ferry area between 11:15 PM and 12:30 PM on 04/12/2021.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
